span_annotations.span: My endo also had me not go up to the highest dose, which would have been my next step. I am currently at 2.4 mg daily. It is still working well.
My doctor says it sounds like depersonalization disorder but we’ll find out in a few weeks when I see a specialist. :/
I'm on mdi and expecting the same conversation this week at my annual review. Last time I was told to raise it because the a1c being low was due to having os many hypos
The math didn’t math so she thought it was best to change ALL my ratios for all the time because it didn’t make sense to her!!
I got that good ol pump recommendation too (I used one for 13 years - I’m good on all that) and told her so. Got the “oH aRe U sUrE it can do x, y, z and a buncha other things you already know!!”

I count myself unbelievably lucky that my Endo has been positive and supportive so far instead of acting like a scolding nanny. My diabetes educator was pretty patronizing but I was fortunately only required to have one session with her.
Also according to some studies but not all that confirmed is alcohol affects insulin sensitivity.
I am a T1 who has been on Saxenda for about 2 months. I use O5 and G6. I have had 2 bad lows in this entire time

I told my endo and she had me change some settings in manual mode, but since then, I haven't had any lows. 

I saw my endo and my A1C decreased from 7.1 to 6.6, my TIR is absurd, like 90%, and I have lost about 15 pounds. This is only 2 months in. I did have side effects in the beginning, head aches, queasiness, I vomited twice mostly due to eating too close to bed time

Usually for about 4 days before my period I had high BGs, was moody, craving carbs, sweets and salty snacks, then my period would start and my BGs would plummet and I would crash!  I had been started on an insulin pump and got help creating a special basal rate just for the premenstrual time.
Generally 2 hours, sometimes 1.5 hours if it’s gone up in that time.

There is no way that someone else can tell you how much insulin to take - we are all different. You really do need to call your doctor. If all you have is a sliding scale, you might want to look for a new doctor, too - that's not a very modern or effective way to manage type 1.

Could be a few things, maybe you are getting ill? Or maybe you missed your basal injection? Maybe your insulin has gone off. I'd start with changing your insulin if possible. If you have missed the basal insulin, you will need significantly more insulin to remain stable, do that until your next scheduled basal injection, don't double up basal if you are not sure whether you took it or not.

If you are ill you will likely need more insulin to remain in range aswell.
Give yourself an injection with the same insulin - do you come down? If you do it probably the site, if you don’t it’s probably the insulin or infection.

Definitely go into it with something substantial in your stomach. I usually go for something fatty and protein based, eggs and hash browns are my go to. Stay hydrated before/during/after. Basic drinking protocol. 

I usually try to make sure I have a CGM in and working so I can spot trouble ahead of time. The biggest problem you’ll probably have is lows, probably hours after drinking while your liver is still busy metabolizing what you’ve drank. You can either be really slack about your blousing during the night, I’ll bolus for any meals I have, but small stuff, candy, mixers, I’ll usually leave until the end of the night. I usually try to do this by including a mixed drink or cup of punch a for every few beers/shots I have. If this seems too cavalier for you, I’ve had lots of success having 15-25 carbs of a snack before bed. I try to pack it in whatever bag I take with me, usually a ziplock bag of oreos or thin mints. I’d also recommend an emergency snack just in case you do dip and have nothing on hand. 

These strategies are really important because glucagons do not work while your body is processing alcohol. When in doubt, aim high, because this isn’t the time to pass out because of a hypo. Have somebody that can recongnize your symptoms really well, this is also really tricky because being low looks and sounds and feels a lot like being drunk.
There aren't ONLY (insulin secreting) beta cells in your pancreas, there are 5 cell types that secrete a whole bunch of hormones -glucagon, insulin, somatostatin, ghrelin, and pancreatic polypeptide
Hypos over a long period can damage short term memory.
sliding scale is an older, not-as-effective way of managing blood sugar
that's not a very modern or effective way to manage type 1
scar tissue starts to become a major issue if you regularly don’t rotate sites
Insulin affects liver release of glycogen which may cause low
Also according to some studies but not all that confirmed is alcohol affects insulin sensitivity
